text: so hi everybody today I'd like to present to you my PhD thesis work on taking inspiration from expert creative
practice to design crowd sourcing techniques for supporting creativity ooh
platforms like Amazon Mechanical Turk and others have made it possible for hundreds of people to come together to
produce creative work at massive scale projects like the Johnny Cash project asked workers to draw individual frames
which were combined to create a reinterpretation of a music video while other past work has looked at how to
achieve more complex projects by building workflows that allow crowd workers to build on each other's work
oops so doing this makes a whole lot of sense because it's this breaking down of
work into independent parts that allows crowdsourcing to be so good at achieving large complex task quickly and at scale
and currently crowds use a number of proven strategies to split up this work
so in many crowdsourcing systems individual workers are encouraged to submit independent submissions that may
net them a monetary bonus or benefit of some kind of its ultimately selected
other systems divide the work into smaller chunks assigning them to workers with the intent of merging work together
at the end so the Johnny Cash project is an example of this as our projects like Galaxy Zoo folded and other tasks where
a large amount of repetitive work like data collection or labeling needs to be done and more recently systems have
explored more complex workflows styles that resemble an assembly line soylent for example propose the work flow
pattern pattern called find fix verify indicating three different tasks that could be done by different workers in
that order two together perform the task of copy editing text research has even
looked at how to get the crowd to create their own workflows based on given goals so all of these strategies requires pre
determining a particular desired outcome and prescribing to crowds exactly how to create that outcome this usually means
that using these strategies crowd workers work very independently any connection between workers is usually in
the form of work being passed from one work or to another and this limits the kind of work that we can crowdsource so
to compare how do experts manage themselves when they creates of the creative processes that expert
creators already use may be an untapped source of reliable creative strategies that may help us understand how the
crowd can influence the direction of complex creative projects so we know for example about experts continually create
and revise constraints to develop purpose for their work they reflect during practice and they make use of
existing patterns for solutions rather than reinventing the wheel so in other words no expert creator simply competes
and votes with themselves they may create alternative solutions to a problem but rather than taking a
solution wholesale as you might see in a crowdsourcing system experts often combine or modify solutions by taking
the bigger picture into account and can even make the judgment call to start over and try a new approach so what if
we could get the crowd to also thoughtfully revise their work as they work if we can do that we might be able
to expand the ability of crowd sourcing to tackle even more complex collaborative projects my research
focuses on adapting expert creative practice into social computing and crowdsourcing environments in order to
make these strategies accessible to a crowd of non-experts that is rather than
breaking down work by splitting it in two independent steps maybe we should enable the crowd to follow a process that looks more like an expert instead
of doing creative crowdsourcing like crowdsourcing maybe we can do creative crowdsourcing like creativity so in this
talk I'll talk about three expert practices that I've been exploring through several projects first I'll talk
about ensemble where I explored how leader created constraints can help a crowd coordinate in writing short
fiction stories then i'll talk about mechanical novel where i looked at how
to get the crowd to engage in reflection and revision on their own we're over 200 unique workers were able to work
together to write short fiction without a leader and lastly I'll talk about mosaic where I looked at how to design
online creative communities so that they focus not just on showing off final successes but on helping creators
support each other while they work and show how you are able to build up a community of creators that shared their
creative processes with each other so
first ensemble this project we looked at the expert practice of creating and revising constraints so in ensembl we structured
crowd work around these constraints rather than a specific overall goal so
most of us are familiar with examples of how the crowd can produce incredible pieces of collaborative work but though
the web has been able to create the great collaborative encyclopedia it hasn't been able to create the great collaborative novel and you would think
that we would be able to take a leaf from the book of one of the most successful crowd powered systems on the web like Wikipedia and apply it to
creative collaboration online but a completely open collaborative system can make it hard for group to the site on
and adhere to a single creative vision on the other hand in highly structured
approaches participants might build up a story piece by piece by adding a few sentences at a time but without the
ability to coordinate at a higher level collaborators end up with incoherent patchwork stories that turn out more
like wild improv games than a novel so what can we do about this from past
research on how creativity works we know that one thing that we can do is make use of constraints to limit and direct
the search through a creative space for a story so with constraints a creative work can be made more manageable by
reducing the space of possible choices and this also make sure that all the people working on the story are brainstorming in the same areas of that
space so in addition rather than following some kind of a linear process we also know that expert writers
structure their writing around goals that they create and revised as they work so what if we adopted these
perspectives on using goals and creative constraints by putting leaders in charge of creating goals to direct work on the
story and putting collaborators potentially the crowd in charge of fleshing out the story with those goals
in mind so based on this we decided to explore potential online collaborative
storytelling strategies by building a tool ensemble based on the hypothesis that the crowd and the individual have
complementary creative strengths so so
to the Sun we built the platform where individual leaders start a story by creating initial structures for stories
using mini writing prompts which is the where the idea of constraints comes in
collaborators can then focus on the type of work that they're good at around these constraints brainstorming
proposing possible segments of writing or discussing potential solutions the
leader can then do things like choose a winning contribution or merge or edit existing contributions to better fit the
overall vision for the story so using this platform the main question that we
wanted to ask was whether or not this division of creative responsibility would produce successful collaborations
so in particular could the crowd support the writing process for this lead author
and to look at this question we ran a month long story writing competition we ran in collaboration with the creative
writing Department here we're over 100 volunteer users from the web start on almost 50 stories together or over 50
stories together out of these 20 were completed and submitted its entries into the competition and so for this study
team sizes were fairly small with a median of two people working on each story we provided a prompt asking teams
to write a story about what happens to stolen bikes and we got a number of interesting stories including a character study of a man who obsessively
steals bikes due due to childhood trauma and a story where bikes try to escape
their bonds and oppressors and journey to bike heaven and this was one example
of the prompts that leaders created with this particular scene asking for details filling out the introduction to the story so as you can see contributors are
conversing with the leader about these high-level story details but in general people would also use these comment
spaces to point out low-level issues like grammar and spelling errors or point out if they've made any changes to
the story so to summarize our findings here we found
that on the leader side of things we just tended to maintain creative Authority with half of their activity being spent revising paragraphs written
themselves so in practice this meant that leaders were manually integrating ideas provided by others and submitted
paragraphs or comments into the story rather than taking contributions as is so in other words leaders were
interpreting contributions for the high level idea being suggested and using them as examples or points of comparison
while manually tweaking existing work
contributors on the other hand were limited to writing comments or paragraphs in response to any prompts
that were provided by the leader so when they submitted when they cemented paragraphs for a story they were able to
do so without overwriting other people's proposals for that section and because of this contributors could use this as a
safe way to show rather than describe their ideas for the story so one participant put it it was harder for
them to describe what they wanted to do rather than to just do it so in this way and someone unexpectedly this feature
that we had built to that was meant to facilitate low level merging of writing work was actually used instead as a way
to clearly communicate high level ideas
so to sum up we saw that leaders play this role of merging work too in order to make it possible for contributions to
add to each other rather than having to compete against each other as in traditional crowdsourcing workflows so
here since we saw that ensemble worked with smaller groups our next question was to ask whether we could achieve a
similar collaboration with larger teams so that thought sparked the creation of
the next project I'm going to talk about mechanical novel so here rather than using leaders to guide a collaborative
work around constraints we looked at how we could get crowds to take on that leader role for themselves while writing short fiction stories so for in Samba
one major bottleneck was this leader who had the coordinate contributions um looking at everything coming in was a
huge burden on one person and leaders told us that coming up with constraints was sometimes difficult for them so the
question with mechanical novel was how can we get crowds to monitor their own and adjust their work accordingly so
like I mentioned earlier existing crowd sourcing systems usually break down complex tasks by splitting them into
independent parts that you can piece together later or by using a workflow to
build on a task step-by-step however
this means that the system's can't crowdsource work that has mutually interdependent parts so for something
like a story changing the name of a character for example requires you to have to go through and change all
mentions of this character elsewhere this gets even more complex if you start
changing more abstract things like a character's motivation so already it's
pretty clear that what an expert creator like an author does to make these types of changes isn't what crowd sourcing
systems can currently do instead when
experts make these kinds of changes they use reflection to engage in a sort of conversation with their work so when
they reflect they continually evaluate whether they like where they're going and whether it's getting them closer to
their vision which itself might still be forming in their head so rather than using a static workflow to create
experts use reflection to determine if they need to make changes and what their next step should be so what would it
look like for a crowd to collaboratively reflect on their work instead of
developing a static workflow to accomplish the static hole we could break down complex work by reflecting on
and revising high-level goals so to do this the crowd can loop between two
phases first they reflect on the work so far to brainstorm and choose a high-level goal to pursue next and then
they revise the work by decomposing that goal into small actionable tasks that guide what edits workers should make so
to explore this technique we created a system called mechanical novel for writing purely crowdsource short fiction
stories hooked into Mechanical Turk the
starts by creating a first draft in response to a story prom so this first draft draft is usually not super great
but it allows the crowd to set an initial rough direction for stories idea
so here we start off with a story prompt the hot air balloon where a boy accidentally flies to a city in the sky
and the crowd writes a short story one paragraph at a time and uses votes to
pick the best text for each section next
the cloud the cloud the crowd starts to reflect to do this we ask workers to critique the story using a simple
feedback structure where the worker rights something that they liked something they wish was different and a speculative what if that offers a
possible change the story could make next oops we use these generated what
ifs as candidates for the crowds next goal for the story so here workers have offered a few different changes like
what if we could learn a little bit more about Malcolm or what if we could expand the ending so that Malcolm gets to explore the cloud the cloud City the
crowd votes to select one of these options as the main high-level goal for work so let's say the crowd votes to
expand the story's ending so that Malcolm can explore the Cloud City oops
ok the crowd then starts the revised phase so after picking this high level goal the crowd votes for which sections
of the story need to change in order to achieve this goal along with specific suggestions for what those changes should be so here the crowd makes a few
votes indicating that maybe most workers think that the last paragraph is the one that needs to change in order to achieve
the goal of expanding the ending and some options workers have written for
expanding the ending is to have Malcolm exit the balloon and explore or maybe to write in a villain that Malcolm has to
defeat before he can leave so workers then vote among these suggestions so let's say that workers think that
Malcolm should get out of the hot air balloon to lick around this
I get the most votes become micro tasks that ask workers to edit the text for a particular section by acting as specific
instructions for how a section should change so at this step work to see a request to incorporate Malcolm getting
out of the hot air balloon into this paragraph when it once edits are made and workers vote for the best version of
edits this ends the revision phase of work and that completes one round of
reflection and revision the process that can then repeat allowing the crowd to choose a new goal and revise a story
again this time tackling perhaps a different problem so in this way the
crowd is able to determine a high level goal for themselves which becomes a measuring stick against which all
workers can see if their contributions are doing the right thing and fitting in with other people's work all without the
need for core leader that coordinates everything so with this system our
hypothesis was that allowing the crowd to revise their goals as they generate creative work will result in better
creative outcomes that then approaches that do not allow for reflection so to look at this I ran two studies the first
was a benchmark evaluation to see whether mechanical novel would be able to detect and fix problems that we
artificially introduced into a short story the second study was the sea of mechanical novel would be able to write
a short story from scratch and to look at the quality of the stories like I've written both of these studies had two
experimental conditions the mechanical novel condition which use the system that I just described and the control
condition which represented a typical crowdsourcing workflow where workers jump straight into voting for how to
edit a story and making edits and skip the part where they choose a high level goal and workers who participated in
these studies were randomly assigned to participate in one of these conditions
so first the benchmark study so with this we wanted to get a sense of mechanical novels strengths and
weaknesses and see if it was something that we wanted to move forward with so
we started out with a short story written by Sarah who's a master student working on the mechanical novel project and also a really good writer she chose
six common types of story problems ranging from low-level things like adding typos and grammar to high level
things like adding unnecessary characters and using the original story as a base she then wrote six new stories
each introducing one of these six problems and so this gave us sort of a gold standard to work from as we knew
exactly where and what the major problems were for each story and how we'd expect someone to fix them we then
ran mechanical novel and the control system over each of these 12 stories for just one revision round and then we
repeated all of that three times lastly we lurked we looked at work as votes for
which paragraphs to edit as well as than the actual edits that they made to paragraph to determine how often crowd
workers were able to detect the problem present in the story as well as how often Cod workers were able to fix the
problem and so for this just to highlight some of the more the most
interesting findings from this we found that mechanical novel was more likely to correctly identify the problematic story
sections for the abrupt ending problem and extra characters problem while the control condition was better at
detecting lower level issues like typos both were equally good at detecting and fixing sudden changes in the narrator's
point of view and these findings carried over to each system strengths and fixing
certain problems as well as mechanical novel workers seem to be better at fixing the abrupt ending and even though
both systems were able to detect out of character dialogue mechanical novel was better at fixing this issue so already
we can sort of see a trend towards mechanical novel being strong at addressing these high level problems with story with plot and with character
while the control system predictably seemed to be better at addressing lower level technical issues like spelling and
grammar so seeing how mechanical novel
my how am I differ from traditional crowdsourcing workflows seem promising so we wanted to see how mechanical novel
would perform in writing a story from scratch so to do this we came up with
five story pumps ranging a variety of topics and from these the cow generated a first draft for each story containing
about six short scenes of texts we then duplicated these first draft so
that the stories in the control condition and in the mechanical novel condition started from the same base text we then ran each story through five
rounds of revisions again with mechanical novel starting out with this critique and what the control condition skipping straight skipping the critique
and jumping straight into choosing which sections of the story to edit so in
addition workers in both conditions who participated in revising the story text where optionally allowed to fill out a
short feedback form to indicate what they thought was difficult or easy about making edits and one stories were
written to evaluate stories for quality we asked 215 Mechanical Turk workers who had not worked on any of the story
writing tasks to compare the control and Mechanical Turk versions for one of the story prompts and we asked Turkish here
to choose which story they thought was better in terms of several dimensions so for example which story is better imagery which story has better story
structure and so on and finally we did an analysis of all story at its critiques made how tasks were decomposed
as well as feedback that we received from workers to look for themes in what workers loss problems and how they
attempted to fix these problems so in
the end over 400 Mechanical Turk tests later and 200 unique workers later we ended up with 10 stories 5 revised by
the control condition and 5 revised by mechanical novel stories took about 11 days to go through five rounds of
revision on average and again these were short stories with stories being about six hundred to a thousand words long and
overall we did find that our readers liked stories written by mechanical novel better to impact this we found
several interesting differences between the mechanical novel and control stories
so first we found that mechanical novel stories had significantly more developed plots readers rated mechanical novel
stories is having more complete story arcs with clearer beginning middles and ends readers also rated mechanical novel
stories as having more original and interesting central story ideas which is interesting considering the fact that
both mechanical novel and control story started from the same base first draft
and the blue elephant story that a crowd workers wrote is a good example of how mechanical novel was able to create a
better story arc so in the original story a young girl realizes her stuffed elephant is gone she looks all over for
it and in the end is reunited with it and finds that it has come to life in the control version workers attempted to
motivate the main character search by briefly describing her relationship with the elephant and also tried to add in a
reason for the elephants disappearance so an improvement but could be better
the mechanical novel version in contrast started with a description of how Kaylee
received the elephant from her grandmother which was the same doll her recently deceased mother had when she was a little girl workers also tied this
idea into the ending which reveals that Kaylee's love for her grandmother was what brought the blue elephant to life
in the end creating the specific theme that kind of threads through the whole story and brings it together second we
found that mechanical novel seems to focus workers efforts towards improving the narrative so it seemed that workers
in the control condition actually spent more of their effort fixing spelling and grammar compared to mechanical novel
workers but in contrast mechanical novel stories were rated as having better imagery and description and writing
style so this and this focus on flushing out the story itself was also
corroborated by the analysis we did of types of edits that workers made to each story where we found that workers in the
mechanical novel condition made significantly more edits that expanded on describing characters while workers
in the control condition trended towards making more edits related to again fixing grammar and spelling so for
example in this the control version of the John Doe John Doe story which is a story about a man who finds himself in
heaven started out like this a very straightforward description of the main character surrounding the mechanical
novel story however uses first-person voice to narrate the main characters findings thoughts and feelings as they
try to process an unfamiliar place
lastly we found that mechanical novel allowed workers to coordinate their creative efforts after analyzing the
feedback that workers wrote after writing or revising story texts we found that mechanical novel workers often
justified their work by saying that they were following the suggestions established by other workers meaning that workers were they were working with
others to achieve this high-level goal workers in the control condition on the
other hand were more trended towards making edits that were more likely to try and focus the stories direction
themselves and they were more likely to try and justify their work by critiquing the story as a whole so by this time
you're probably curious as to what one of these stories actually looked like so I'll walk through the control and mechanical novel version of one of the
stories workers wrote during the study so this particular story is about is I
guess like a film noir type story titled number 16 and was about a serial killer who's target suddenly disappears so this
initial first draft of the story as you might expect was filled with inconsistencies the very first paragraph
starts out with a major plot twist where the to be victim actually catches the main character of following her and points a gun at him but the next
paragraph continues as if that hadn't happened describing the serial killer as waiting patiently to make his next move
and later on in the story the point of view changes from the serial killer to
the victim suddenly drawing from the plot twist idea earlier in the story instead to narrating the victims
thoughts as she tries to hunt down the serial killer instead but then the story
ends with a serial killer maybe killing the victim it's not clear and that's how it ends so in the control version of the
story workers were able to remove this early plot twist and change the ending so that the victim does turn the tables
on the serial killer but by fixing these issues they ended up removing much of the story arc including that kind of
important plot twist that activist foreshadowing for that for that ending resulting in kind of a monotone plot and
an ending that seems kind of random in contrast the mechanical novel version
of the story like the control version changes the ending so that the tables are turned on the killer but also
removes well rather than removing the plot twist the early plot twist altogether transforms it into kind of a
foreshadowing for later parts of the plot so instead of the victim catching the serial killer following her she
actually kind of bumps into him and asked him if like oh like are you okay or you need anything he's like oh no I'm
fine and she acts oblivious whereas later on you find out that she actually knew everything that was happening so
that was really interesting in addition mechanical novels workers also added
back stories for the serial killer and the victim to explain why they're doing what they're doing in the story just
another example of how mechanical novels seem to focus more on expanding characters so in summary we found that
workers in the mechanical novel condition focused on higher level story problems than workers in the control
condition and we're less likely to try and hijack the direction of the story when contributing work workers were able
to select a reasonable high level goals for themselves and use these goals to break down the task of revising a short
story into coordinated actions so the
last project I'm going to talk about is mosaic so where ensemble and mechanical novel specifically looked at translating
a certain expert creative practice for use in crowd work with mosaic I wanted to look at expert mindsets failure
struggle unexpected setbacks and new inspirations are all part of creative work so how can we encourage this in the
design of social systems for creators so
to set the stage for where this idea is coming from online creative communities today like deviantart pixiv and dribble
focus on showcasing completed work creating a climate where creators aim to produce work that isn't impressive as
possible to attract viewers and fans and this is a great opportunity to get feedback from others and to look at
examples of other people's really cool work and creators do try to capitalize
this in a lot of ways sometimes they carve out social spaces for sharing in progress work that will create and
curate tutorials it or organized event specifically for tackling creative challenges and this
makes sense because we already know from past literature and creativity that improving skills centers around
continually assessing one one's creative process based on feedback and exploratory experiments so obviously
many creators already know this which is why they try to foster these activities based around creative process but
despite these efforts to help each other in development and growth creators find themselves having to compete against
impressive finished work when uploading earlier and finished work to explain their process processes to each other
which may discourage people from participating in these activities but
what if creative communities were designed from the get-go to allow creators to share a creative process as first-class content rather than just
sharing finished work creators could share in progress snapshots of work to illustrate what they did and why so by
designing a social environment that rewards sharing early work we may create better opportunities for creators to not
only learn specific techniques from each other but also enable them to reflect more effectively on their own work and
on others work so to get a sense of how
community like this might compare against existing our communities I first interviewed ten artists about there are
communities that they already use to show their work an overall interviewee said that they do mainly use existing
sites like deviantart facebook and tumblr to share their artwork for the purpose of getting as much exposure as
they can and while they have and while many of them have post works in progress
on these sites in the past these were mainly to serve mostly a social purpose kind of like a hey here's what i'm up to
here's kind of a sneak peek at what i would i do kind of thing and the reason
is because uh there are many technical or social barriers that they have to
face when trying to share their process such as having to go through a tedious process of concatenated a bunch of
pictures into a single image or being seen as spammy for posting too many
pictures of the same artwork at different stages preventing them from posting substantial content more often
so with the barriers that these artists mentioned in mind I designed and launched mosaic an online social art
platform where the primary method of sharing artwork is to upload multiple images illustrating the creative process
the steps that an artist takes to create a piece of artwork so for example just
to kind of walk through how it works say we have a mosaic user name cookie cat who just started a still life oil painting of their favorite dessert so
they might create a work in progress representing their first step which is drawing a sketch and this work in
progress on mosaic would include a description of any reasoning behind their steps such as why they chose a certain type of subject matter or how
they chose a certain visual composition related works in progress are grouped
together in a project which represents a single creative work so cookie cat might
create a project representing their still-life cookie painting adding works in progress representing stages of development of their artwork from sketch
to under painting maybe to blocking and colors and so on other social features
on mosaic an able artist to view what others are doing so the home page consists of a feed of recent activity
and shows comments new projects and new updates to existing projects you can
also search for projects by keyword or even by specific type of work in progress and all this put together
allows creators to focus on sharing knowledge with each other so say we have another user named donut dog who happens
to see that cookie cat has recently added an update to a painting very similar to the kind of painting that
donut dog wants to make and so they click to take a look and don't know dog is surprised by cookie cats use of an
underpainting to kind of blackout shadows and light early in the process which is a technique that they're not as
familiar with so donut dog favorites this project to subscribe to this project updates in the future and leaves
a comment thanking cookie cat for teaching something new so in this way by
centering users interactions around sharing process mosaic is able to unlock a number of people interactions between creators
such as including being able to compare your own creative process with others learn new techniques and provide
feedback in a specific timely way so my
hypothesis with mosaic was that sharing creative processes is difficult for creators because existing creative
communities are designed to reward sharing high-quality creative outcomes so instead an alternative design for a
community designed around sharing works in progress may encourage creators to share early work and learn from each
other so in order to understand the difficulties artists faced when seeking or sharing works in progress online we
conducted a field deployment of mosaic over the course of four weeks and invited users from artists from
hobbyists art communities to use mosaic to host snapshots of works in progress we're snapshots of work in progress is
of whatever they happen to be working on and during the study period we logged all community activity including the
creation of projects work-in-progress snapshots project favorites user follows and so on and finally at the end of the
study period we conducted semi-structured interviews with 10 of the most active mosaic users as measured
by their commenting and project posting activity to understand whether posting works in progress affected their creative practice and how they
interacted with other mosaic users so by
the end of the study period a total of forty-six users created 69 projects with projects containing an average of about
five works in progress each and each receiving an average of about two comments and there's an interesting
range in the types of images that people would upload so while many people uploaded a typical step-by-step set of
images like in this example others would post work of their post photos of their
work environment and tools or include maybe initial exploratory sketches that weren't ultimately used and speaking
with interview interview participants we did find that mosaic seemed to provide a significantly different experience from
existing art communities that they frequent so first participants described posting about their process as a useful
way for them to left on their own work so a few artists including this participant pointed out
that documenting their process on mosaic would be useful to their future selves to help them remember that this
beautiful painting that they're so proud of actually did start out kind of horrible so they don't feel bad about a horrible start to a new project secondly
works in progress on mosaic seem to allow other creators to pinpoint the intent of the Creator posting artwork
leading to inform feedback from the community as a whole participants found this useful as this meant that they
could use other users comments as a mirror to kind of help them reflect on whether or not they were able to achieve
their goals posting works in progress
also implicitly enforced a kind of a community of reciprocity so many artists
like this participant mentioned that a principle of fairness or a desire to give back to the community drove their
motivation to create tutorials or write feedback for others but enforcing this fairness can be quite difficult on
existing sites like diviner in contrast many participants described both posting
works in progress and posting comments for others as kind of teaching opportunities on mosaic so in other
words creators ended up framing the their mosaic projects that they uploaded it as kind of gifts of knowledge to
others and this was the same mechanism through which people received feedback and help and lastly we found that mosaic
allowed artists to feel less apprehensive about sharing their work so on existing sites the goal is to compete
with others for views and comments but in contrast mosaic centred user activity around making updates on progress of
artwork creating an environment where sharing process was something that everybody was doing and making people
focus less on the final outcome and more on sharing a journey so in summary
mosaic demonstrates some of the benefits of designing creativity support tools and communities around outcomes other
than traditional success such as experimentation exploration or even failure these are all clearly important
parts of the creative process and creating such tools would help expand the ways in which
social systems and other technology can help support creators so in this talk I
presented three projects ensemble mechanical novel and mosaic through
these project I explored how adapting existing existing creative practices by experts can help us design new kinds of
crowdsourcing workflows and social computing systems for accomplishing collaborative open-ended creative tasks
these projects also touch on specific design patterns that came out of embedding expert practices into social
systems for example easing constraints to help collaborative collaborator strike a balance between free creativity
and working in sync with others letting reflection dr collaborative action to allow crowds to work together flexibly
and aiming to create a me for creating a social environment that embraces process
rather than trying to act as a gallery but more broadly my works a major
contribution to the field of HCI is creating crowdsourcing and social competing systems that focus on
supporting a creative process so through ensemble mechanical novel I developed a
technique for extracting strategies from expert practice and embedding them into the design of collaborative tools for
accomplishing complex creative work with crowds in all of my projects I
contributed working proof of concept social systems and crowdsourcing workflows to show that an expert
practice can be incorporated with the design of a system to improve the quality of creative outcomes and through
mosaic I expanded the possible space of creativity support tools to include tools that value process and not just
final outcome specifically proposing design affordances like sharing the process behind artwork instead of just
the staring this process behind artwork and show how this affects interactions between creators in an online community
and these contributions open up a number of interesting avenues for future work
first we could explore other designs for crowdsourcing systems that allow crowd workers to direct their own work so for
example orienting work around high-level goals like we did a mechanical novel may
be great in early stages of writing a story when ideas are still developing but late in later stages when you might
want to actually focus on cleaning up spelling and grammar and fixing the sentences that'll flow well a more
traditional crowdsourcing system may actually be actually be more helpful so it would be interesting to see if a
crowdsourcing system could dynamically adjust the degree to which it focused on
high level or low level work and see how that affects the creative output of the crowd secondly a major area of research
has drawn on the fact that the crowd is physically spread in many different locations so rather than maybe relying
on ad-hoc behavior or some sort of central governing figure we might be able to use the strategies that we saw a
mechanical novel to self-organize for example maybe citizen reporting efforts or humanitarian efforts in cases of like
a natural disaster when central direction isn't readily available and
lastly we could expand the design direction we explored with mosaic and
perhaps generate a new design space of creativity support tools and communities designed around sharing process so
mosaic was just kind of the tip of the iceberg there you could add on to this direction by thinking about a community
that allows creators to maybe create techniques into personal tool boxes or
libraries or imagined communities where people explicitly showcase failures instead of focusing on success thinking
beyond just traditional success opens opportunities for new ways like creators could help support each other okay so
just before I wrap things up I want to thank you all for listening um I also want to thank a lot of other people as
well first and foremost my advisor Michael Bernstein who's been a great source of support for me not only in
